natural problem: How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle?
natural solution: By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. triangle x \<le> 180"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. triangle x \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "\<exists> x. triangle x > 90"
and h3 : "sum triangle {1,2,3} = 180"
shows  "\<exists>! x. triangle x > 90"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. triangle x \<le> 180"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. triangle x \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "\<exists> x. triangle x > 90"
and h3 : "sum triangle {1,2,3} = 180"
shows  "\<exists>! x. triangle x > 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a triangle, the sum of all angles is 180 degrees and each angle is between 0 and 180 degrees. If there is an angle greater than 90 degrees, prove that there is exactly one such angle.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real, real, real) set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>(a, b, c) \<in> triangle. a < 90 \<and> b < 90 \<and> c > 90"
shows  "card {angle. \<exists>(a, b, c) \<in> triangle. angle = a \<or> angle = b \<or> angle = c \<and> angle > 90} = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real, real, real) set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>(a, b, c) \<in> triangle. a < 90 \<and> b < 90 \<and> c > 90"
shows  "card {angle. \<exists>(a, b, c) \<in> triangle. angle = a \<or> angle = b \<or> angle = c \<and> angle > 90} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a set of triangles, each triangle has two angles less than 90 degrees and one angle greater than 90 degrees. How many unique angles greater than 90 degrees are there in the set? The final answer is 1.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a + b + c = 180"
and h1 : "a > 90 \<or> b > 90 \<or> c > 90"
shows  "\<exists> !x. x = a \<and> x > 90 \<or> x = b \<and> x > 90 \<or> x = c \<and> x > 90"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a + b + c = 180"
and h1 : "a > 90 \<or> b > 90 \<or> c > 90"
shows  "\<exists> !x. x = a \<and> x > 90 \<or> x = b \<and> x > 90 \<or> x = c \<and> x > 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a triangle with angles $a$, $b$, and $c$ (in degrees), if the sum of the angles is $180^\circ$ and one of the angles is greater than $90^\circ$, prove that there is exactly one angle that is greater than $90^\circ$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A > 90 ∧ B < 90 ∧ C < 90"
and h1 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "obtuse_angles_in_triangle = 1"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A > 90 ∧ B < 90 ∧ C < 90"
and h1 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "obtuse_angles_in_triangle = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a triangle with angles A, B, and C, if angle A is greater than 90 degrees and both angles B and C are less than 90 degrees, and the sum of angles A, B, and C is 180 degrees, how many obtuse angles does the triangle have? The answer is 1.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real \<times> real \<times> real) set"
and obtuse_angle :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a,b,c). a+b+c = 180 \<and> a > 90 \<or> b > 90 \<or> c > 90}"
and h1 : "obtuse_angle = {x. x > 90}"
shows  "card (triangle \<inter> obtuse_angle) = 1"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real \<times> real \<times> real) set"
and obtuse_angle :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a,b,c). a+b+c = 180 \<and> a > 90 \<or> b > 90 \<or> c > 90}"
and h1 : "obtuse_angle = {x. x > 90}"
shows  "card (triangle \<inter> obtuse_angle) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a set of triangles where each triangle is defined by three angles (a, b, c) that add up to 180 degrees, and at least one of the angles is greater than 90 degrees, intersected with a set of angles greater than 90 degrees, how many matches are there? The final answer is 1.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "triangle = (\<lambda>x. if x \<in> {1,2,3} then angle x else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x \<in> {1,2,3}. 0 < triangle x \<and> triangle x < pi"
and h2 : "triangle 1 + triangle 2 + triangle 3 = pi"
and h3 : "\<exists>x \<in> {1,2,3}. pi / 2 < triangle x"
shows  "\<exists>!x \<in> {1,2,3}. pi / 2 < triangle x"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "triangle = (\<lambda>x. if x \<in> {1,2,3} then angle x else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x \<in> {1,2,3}. 0 < triangle x \<and> triangle x < pi"
and h2 : "triangle 1 + triangle 2 + triangle 3 = pi"
and h3 : "\<exists>x \<in> {1,2,3}. pi / 2 < triangle x"
shows  "\<exists>!x \<in> {1,2,3}. pi / 2 < triangle x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider a triangle with angles labeled 1, 2, and 3. Each angle measures strictly between 0 and π (180 degrees) and the sum of all three angles is equal to π. If there exists an angle that measures more than π/2 (90 degrees), show that there can be exactly one such angle.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes angle1 angle2 angle3 :: real
assumes h0 : "angle1 + angle2 + angle3 = 180"
and h1 : "angle1 > 90 \<or> angle2 > 90 \<or> angle3 > 90"
shows  "card {angle \<in> {angle1, angle2, angle3}. angle > 90} = 1"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes angle1 angle2 angle3 :: real
assumes h0 : "angle1 + angle2 + angle3 = 180"
and h1 : "angle1 > 90 \<or> angle2 > 90 \<or> angle3 > 90"
shows  "card {angle \<in> {angle1, angle2, angle3}. angle > 90} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given that the sum of angles angle1, angle2, and angle3 is 180 degrees, and one of these angles is greater than 90 degrees, prove that there can only be one angle greater than 90 degrees.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real * real * real) set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a, b, c) | a b c. a + b + c = 180 \<and> a > 90 \<or> b > 90 \<or> c > 90}"
shows  "card {x \<in> triangle. fst x > 90 \<or> snd x > 90 \<or> (fst o snd) x > 90} = 1"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real * real * real) set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a, b, c) | a b c. a + b + c = 180 \<and> a > 90 \<or> b > 90 \<or> c > 90}"
shows  "card {x \<in> triangle. fst x > 90 \<or> snd x > 90 \<or> (fst o snd) x > 90} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a set of triangles where the sum of the angles in each triangle equals 180 degrees and at least one angle in each triangle is greater than 90 degrees. How many triangles in this set have at least one angle greater than 90 degrees? The final answer is 1.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A > 90 \<or> B > 90 \<or> C > 90"
shows  "(if A > 90 then 1 else 0) + (if B > 90 then 1 else 0) + (if C > 90 then 1 else 0) = 1"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A > 90 \<or> B > 90 \<or> C > 90"
shows  "(if A > 90 then 1 else 0) + (if B > 90 then 1 else 0) + (if C > 90 then 1 else 0) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a triangle with angles A, B, and C (in degrees), if the sum of the angles is 180 degrees and one of the angles is greater than 90 degrees, show that only one angle can be greater than 90 degrees.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real * real * real) set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a, b, c)| a real and b real and c real and a + b + c = 180 and a > 90 or b > 90 or c > 90}"
shows  "card {x \<in> triangle. fst x > 90 or snd x > 90 or trd x > 90} = 1"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many obtuse interior angles are in an obtuse triangle? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 By definition, an obtuse triangle contains one obtuse interior angle. It cannot contain more than one because an obtuse angle has measure greater than 90 degrees and the sum of all the interior angles in any triangle is 180 degrees.
 Thus, there is $\boxed{1}$ obtuse angle.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "(real * real * real) set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a, b, c)| a real and b real and c real and a + b + c = 180 and a > 90 or b > 90 or c > 90}"
shows  "card {x \<in> triangle. fst x > 90 or snd x > 90 or trd x > 90} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a set of triangles where each triangle is represented by the set of its three angles (a, b, c) in degrees, and the sum of the angles for each triangle is 180 degrees, how many triangles have at least one angle greater than 90 degrees? The answer is one.
